column1: Æneas and Anchises received the stranger kindly
column3: and asked him who he was
column4: and how he came to be in that desolate country. He answered that he was an Ithacan
column6: and that he had been one of the companions of Ulysses in his wanderings. He related the adventures of the Ithacan hero in the cave of Polyphemus
column8: having been by accident left behind when his comrades escaped
column9: had since led a wretched existence in the woods
column10: living on wild berries and roots
column11: and continually in dread lest he should be seen by the Cyclops. He advised Æneas to lose no time in quitting the country
column12: lest the ferocious shepherds should discover and destroy them. Even as Achæmenides spoke
column13: Polyphemus was seen accompanying his flock to their pasture. So tall was he of stature that he carried the trunk of a pine-tree as a staff to guide his footsteps. Reaching the sea he stepped into it
column14: and bent down to bathe the wound inflicted by Ulysses.
